Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I woke up to the echo of last night’s argument with Mia still ringing in my ears. She barely looked at me as she got ready for work, her silence heavier than any words. We’d reached a breaking point—she said she wasn’t sure if we should even be together anymore. I knew I had to talk to her, to try and fix things before the distance between us became permanent. But as I reached for my phone to text her, I remembered: today was my only chance to swing by my parents’ house and grab my passport, the only valid ID I had left. Without it, I couldn’t vote tomorrow, and I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss this election. The clock was ticking. If I went to see Mia at lunch, I’d miss my window to get the ID. If I went for the ID, I’d be putting my relationship on hold at the worst possible moment. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations—be the boyfriend who fights for us, or the citizen who shows up. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, paralyzed by the choice.
